text:
If you have a junit4 test case with timeout set, @Test(timeout=1000), the stack
trace from an error looks like:

        at java.util.concurrent.FutureTask$Sync.innerRun(FutureTask.java:269)
        at java.util.concurrent.FutureTask.run(FutureTask.java:123)
        at
java.util.concurrent.ThreadPoolExecutor$Worker.runTask(ThreadPoolExecutor.java:650)
        at
java.util.concurrent.ThreadPoolExecutor$Worker.run(ThreadPoolExecutor.java:675)
        at java.lang.Thread.run(Thread.java:595)
        at BTreeTest.assertSameSortedMap(BTreeTest.java:124)
        at BTreeTest.compTest(BTreeTest.java:493)

The thread and j.u.concurrent things should be filtered out, they come from the
junit harness.
creator: bmaurer@andrew.cmu.edu
jglick@apache.org
text:
Not really safe to filter those methods since they may well be used in other
contexts. May be possible to filter that exact sequence of method calls.

Agreed that this is somewhat nasty. However, the filtering that is *already*
done (of reflection methods) is also risky.

The real solution is for the JUnit code to expose the target method exception
(or whatever that exception class is called) that the reflection gives off. 
This would tell us exactly what frames needed to be removed. However, this would
involve junit changing api.

If we were doing junit4, we might be able to do our own custom runner. I'd
personally rather that this be in junit -- it'd benefit ant, eclipse and the
console runner. However, the response from the junit devs hasn't been good...
